974 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
18 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
12 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
7
Non recommandÃ©
13.3 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 5 octobre 2022
Ctrl Alt Ego is one of the best concepts imaginable developed by the least competent people imaginable.

It's playable ENTIRELY on the strength of its concept, even as it attempts to bungle the execution of it at every possible turn.

The pitch is that you are a disembodied mind that jumps from device to device as you try to disable/avoid the facility's guardians and eventually do... something vague that I kind of missed. When possessing your "primary" form, the BUG, you also get some special powers that are liberally lifted from Dishonored, Prey, etc. there's nothing original there but it's all stand-bys of the genre it attempts to be.

See, that's another thing to address. I've seen people call this an immersive sim, I think even some of the marketing material does, but it isn't. â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ aside, an immersive sim is about being in a believable environment that you can see as something other than a gameplay level, as a work environment, lab or living space, and then interacting with believable things. The environments in CAE are more like Portal levels. This isn't to say this is bad by itself, I loved Portal and Portal 2, I just feel like it misrepresents what the game is.

Anyway, this all sounds pretty good so far, right?

Well too bad, they screwed it up.

Firstly, you've got a game that often involves physics manipulations where the physics are awful. Even while doing something as simple as riding an elevator, your possessed item will attempt to topple over. Physics objects regularly block necessary items. Carried objects will occasionally simply choose to clip outside of the level. Sometimes you carry something and it just explodes in your face.

Secondly, the UI is designed in some sort of very specialized circle of Hell. Possessing something always leaves you looking at a wall or similar, no matter how the object is otherwise facing, and any time there are two vaguely approximate objects to possess, it's suffering to make sure the game picks the right one. You also generally possess machines that are about two feet tall, and have to get items out of containers that are three feet tall, forcing you to battle the camera and sometimes jump on top of and into the container just to get things out of it.

Pointless possessions. You have to possess buttons to press them, and notepads to read them(while oddly enough you can read stationary computer screens just fine by walking up to them), and a number of other such pointlessly fiddly things. There are plenty of buttons in the game you just PUSH, and then piles of them that you have to possess, flipping around your PoV and making it clunky to get back to where you started. This sucks and is bad. You can't even skip some of these because even the pure "lore" items provide EGO which is one of the game's important power usage "currencies."

The game wants you to do stealth, but you're piloting something with a 50-degree FoV and all the acrobatic prowess of a beached sea cucumber, which means that even if you plot the perfect heist, you're going to get held up against a juicebox or a screwdriver.

All this comes together in a way that makes the game feel even when you're doing things right, like you're doing things wrong. Oh and I also hit one puzzle that I think is legitimately impossible without glitching it out with the right powers(which you may or may not have, still, optional puzzle) since the bot you're supposed to possess to navigate a maze can't navigate the maze, or possibly it's just that you may softlock the maze by opening a box in the wrong order.

Plus just, a bunch of other small annoying bugs like a door that resets to closed every time you reach it, and then the first time each time you press the open button it re-closes again immediately afterwards.

Lastly, but not least, there is one(1) voiced character in this game, who is omnipresent, and they found possibly the least charismatic person imaginable for this important starring role. I wanted to brain him with a wrench from the first sentence, I would rather just have read text entries than deal with that.

So long story short: It's INCREDIBLY sad that they executed the game as badly as they did, because it had WILD amounts of potential. Do better next time, maybe do even a marginal amount of beta-testing.
 
PurpleXVI
897 produits enregistrÃ©s
7
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile

Proves that sticking to a strong new vision is what's missing from today's industry. A modern classic that doesn't distract the player with classic game design conventions that end up breaking immersion. It punches way above its weight coming from a 2 person studio. Thank you for keeping this genre alive!

402 produits enregistrÃ©s

4 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation amusante
4
Non recommandÃ©
0.5 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 28 mars 2023
As soon as I started playing it I knew I messed up.

Prey is my favorite game, so I bought this on the dozens of recommendations that said it was similar. What in the world are people talking about? Nothing about this game is similar to Prey in the slightest.

The graphics and physics are extremely, what's the word... cheap and unrealistic. The "immersion" is just point A to point B puzzles for the sake of being puzzles. Nothing about this game is enthralling, thought-provoking, or attention grabbing. It's like a (very) low-budget cross between Portal and The Stanley Parable, but less fun and significantly less aesthetically pleasing. I've drunkenly created more attractive environments in 30 minutes using 1999's Unreal Editor.

The difference between Prey and this game is the difference between me paying any amount of money for a game, and wishing I had stubbed my toe instead of playing it.

This game might have a great concept, but it's so under-cooked that it's painful to have it on my computer. I've already requested a refund and uninstalled it and nothing anyone says can convince me to reverse course.

I mean absolutely no disrespect to the humble, creative team who made this unique game, but the fans (maybe friends of the developers or even the developers themselves on alt accounts?) who are talking so highly about it aren't doing it any favors in the long run. Just give it a fully honest critique and please leave Prey out of your mouth.

And... run it by someone before calling it finished and putting it out there. My 2 cents.
 
Ukraine!

The game is 100% immersive and proud of it, everything can be done in as many ways as you like.
The gameplay gets a little repetitive towards the end, but only a little.

Artistic Cat
0
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
14.9 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 5 janvier
Was a pretty fun game overall. Obviously this is not a AAA immersive sim like the neo-deus ex games or dishonoured, etc, but it certainly carries on their spirit even if it can't match all of their breadth. There's definitely good depth to this game, but a lot of its depth lies in sort of "pushing against the simulation". so to speak. Doing things that almost don't feel intended, but are.

Pure stealth is much harder and possibly more boring than Deus Ex or Dishonoured but I don't think that's entirely a bad thing- those two games end up being more stealth games than anything else, whereas here it's much more up to you how to approach things. It almost gave me the feeling of a VR game like bonelabs, where you're just interacting with the environment without feeling like there's a way you "should" be playing the game, and a lot of people will have different experiences.

All in all, I'd recommend it. It was a good time, though I am not sure I'll replay it, partially because of how easily I got everything. Definitely a sleeper gem, though!
 
Loquacious Lasagna

The levels are very well thought out with what you are given and there is no point where you are not utilizing a good portion of your kit. Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 22 dÃ©cembre 2023
Ctrl Alt Ego advertises itself as "The problem solving creativity of games like Prey, System Shock, and Deus Ex, mixed with a campy British sci-fi vibe a la Red Dwarf or Doctor Who, and incorporating stealth from games like Dishonored, Hitman, and Watch Dogs" and it backs up those claims with a very fun immersive sim that exceeded my expectations.

If you enjoy these games and shows you will not regret picking up this game.

Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 17 dÃ©cembre 2023
It's a pretty cool game with a super unique mechanic of hoping between things. It's clear there's a good amount of systems to play around with to shape your experience as you like but I'm gonna stop playing it cause it's very focused on its puzzles and that's just not my jam. Maybe if I came back and chose some of the gun modules that'd be a better playthrough for me but as it is there isn't a clear way to respec and just try new builds on the fly; it seems like you'll need whole ass new playthrough just to see how modules will work and what you'll like. You should still give it a shot and see if you enjoy it. I still think it was worth the short playtime I had with it.

RecommandÃ©
29.2 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 8 dÃ©cembre 2023
I'm going to tell you a bit about my experience with this game.

It all started with my love for Prey and looking for other immersive sym games for me to play. While looking at Dillon Rogers twitter (X) due to him developing the game I'm most excited about, I saw that he was recommending some games, one of them had a fantastic cover art that immediately caught my eye and I decided to look for it on Steam. With just 300 reviews I decided to buy it as soon as I could get a chance.

What comes after that is a great and possibly the most immersive and most impressive game I have played in a long time. It wasn't all positive at first, I tried the game for around 8 hours first, reaching the Chapter 6 and considering that it was extremely hard and even if I liked the concept of the game and mechanics that maybe it wasn't for me and that was ok. I decided to give it another chance after a couple of weeks, I restarted my playthrough and, for some unknown reason even to me, decided to up the challenge and play it on Strict. During these 21 hours (11.5 in game time) I had an amazing time and it was all due to having a different perspective on how to overcome the situations. On my first playthrough I was playing it like a shooter, getting the gun.exe first and basically shooting my way through those first six chapters and some stealth sprinkled through there. On the second playthrough I found different paths, different ways to unlock doors, hack through stuff, fly through the level being the best bodyless EGO I could be and I loved each second of it.

This game is the purest definition of a hidden gem that I have ever seen, I'm not that into making written reviews of games I just want more people to find this game and experience this incredible game.

If my review wasn't clear enough on how much I LOVE this game, or maybe you just want a quick score: 10/10.

RecommandÃ©
63.2 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 27 novembre 2023
An amazing and unique game that you absolutely need to give a try.
Despite the comedy that made me think the campaign wasnt very serious, the story is surprisingly interesting and good. The campaign has a very good length and a lot of replayability; i have played the game by stealthing around everything and by going head on into the enemies and both were very fun experiences.
The gameplay is very fun and deep once you get the basics of it, the tools are very fun and interesting to experiment with and the level design is fantastic and compliments the tools very well; you have something interesting to do with most tools in every situation, and even options for going in with no tools at all. You really can just play it however you want.
Definitely a game that should be played by everyone.
(Also the devs should sell bug plushies/figures fr fr, the design grew on me a lot the more i played)

82 produits enregistrÃ©s

1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
36.3 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 27 octobre 2023
Spectacular game. It isn't for everyone but if you're like me and find that you've acquired a taste for hidden gems then this game is among the finest of them. It is shockingly long and open ended. There was never a moment where I felt I had too few tools, and the game enables the use of all of them. This game isn't scared of you becoming extremely powerful and even enables it by allowing the player total freedom to decide how they want to go about doing things with all of that power.

Spoilers:

Also want to mention that the ending is the perfect way to make you feel instantly trapped. Going from the total freedom of the final level, to assuming that you're going to gain EVEN MORE freedom, only to be suddenly trapped with nowhere to go felt like having all of my limbs torn off at once. Never before have I felt that way but Ctrl Alt Ego did it and for that reason it will stick in my mind.

TL;DR
Buy the frickin game already, man.

7.8 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 27 octobre 2023
**heavy British accent*

Ah, you've got a discerning taste in gaming, I must say.

Ctrl Alt Ego takes that essence-switching mechanic from Geist and blasts it into orbit. The game offers that same thrill of embodying different entities, but now you're doing it in a richly crafted space station, dialed up to eleven.

Like Geist, Ctrl Alt Ego isn't just playing a game, it's a tactical switch of perspectives. It captures that blend of high-stakes action and psychological gameplay, but the setting and humor give it a uniquely British spin. For you, it's not just a sequel to a beloved concept; it's an evolution.

The future you liked in "Geist" is fully realized here in "Ctrl Alt Ego." This is not just another title; it's a paradigm shift.


ASCII art of Peter Molyneux:

____
/ \
| 0 0 |
\ ^ /
\___/


**End transmission**

No meio de uma indÃºstria muito saturada onde todos os novos jogos sÃ£o mais do mesmo (atÃ© no cenÃ¡rio indie nota-se certa estagnaÃ§Ã£o tambÃ©m), Ã© muito legal descobrir um jogo divertido e criativo que consegue apresentar algo totalmente novo, partindo de uma premissa jÃ¡ existente. Esse jogo Ã© o Ctrl Alt Ego.

Ctrl Alt Ego Ã© um Simulador Imersivo filosÃ³fico com alto foco na resoluÃ§Ã£o de problemas e exploraÃ§Ã£o para encontrar meios diversos para concluir o mesmo objetivo. Nele, controlamos um â€œego sem corpoâ€ que, a partir da orientaÃ§Ã£o de um estranho indivÃ­duo conhecido como Doutor Everyman, devemos destruir um parasita que se alimenta do ego de outros robÃ´s. NÃ£o apenas isso, mas descobrir tambÃ©m o que aconteceu com a estaÃ§Ã£o espacial, com o doutor, e descobrir quem somos.

Sendo um ego sem corpo, o jogador pode se mover livremente pelos locais controlando (se teleportando em) outros dispositivos para descobrir novos pontos de interesse e meios de alcanÃ§ar os objetivos. Controle cÃ¢meras e veja a Ã¡rea ao redor, controle portas e elevadores para liberar novos locais, controle robÃ´s agressivos como os PAIs e as MÃƒEs, ou controle cachorrinhos inofensivos e passe despercebido por eles. HÃ¡ uma grande variedade de dispositivos que Ã© possÃ­vel controlar que abrem novas possibilidades para a jogatina, mas claro, desde que tenha ego o suficiente para controlar eles.

Aliada a essa liberdade de controlar outros dispositivos, os jogadores terÃ£o tambÃ©m a sua disposiÃ§Ã£o o Bug-22, um bot que foi banido (assim como todos os Bugs) que Ã© capaz de instalar programas em si que expandem as possibilidades de jogatina, sendo alguns deles o programa de vÃ´o, de ficar invisÃ­vel, de teleporte, de imprimir novos objetos, ou de equipar uma escopeta. No entanto, como os bugs foram banidos, o Bug-22 Ã© alvo fÃ¡cil para outros robÃ´s agressivos e sistemas de alarme, mas nÃ£o se preocupe, pois nÃ£o Ã© possÃ­vel perder em Ctrl Alt Ego. Se vocÃª perder seu Bug-22 de alguma forma, vocÃª sempre pode reimprimir ele nas estaÃ§Ãµes apropriadas.

Por ser um Simulador Imersivo, o jogador Ã© livre para pÃ´r a criatividade em prÃ¡tica para resolver os problemas da forma que achar mais conveniente, e isso Ã© reforÃ§ado pelo prÃ³prio jogo em uma mensagem em um tablet, que diz que nÃ£o existe jeito certo ou errado de jogar, que hÃ¡ diferentes rotas e meios de concluir um objetivo, e que Ã© possÃ­vel fazer uma bagunÃ§a, e mesmo assim ficar tudo bem. Se em algum momento o jogador achar que â€œfez algo erradoâ€, Ã© para parar de achar isso imediatamente, pois tudo o que o jogador fez ou pode fazer Ã© totalmente intencional.

Partindo para outros aspectos, o jogo possui uma estÃ©tica geral inspirada em um futuro distÃ³pico representado nos programas britÃ¢nicos de TV dos anos 70, com seus ambientes futuristas coloridos e iluminados, e robÃ´s e dispositivos com aparÃªncia, nomes, descriÃ§Ãµes e sons engraÃ§ados. A trilha sonora Ã© minimalista e divertida, combina perfeitamente com o jogo. Graficamente, o jogo Ã© ok, no entanto ela casa perfeitamente com a estÃ©tica do jogo, mostrando assim um jogo bem agradÃ¡vel de ver.

Se tratando de bugs (nÃ£o, nÃ£o os robÃ´s, dessa vez sÃ£o bugs mesmo) eu encontrei bem poucos, e nenhum deles chegou a atrapalhar a jogatina. O jogo tem uma boa otimizaÃ§Ã£o, mas fica notoriamente pesado no Ãºltimo capÃ­tulo, onde o local Ã© gigante e tem muita coisa acontecendo ao mesmo tempo. No geral, deve rodar em qualquer coisa (se rodou no meu I5 de terceira geraÃ§Ã£o, deve rodar no seu PC sem problemas).

No geral, Ctrl Alt Ego Ã© um divertido jogo inovador e adequado para todos os perfis de jogadores, desde crianÃ§as a adultos, jogadores veteranos ou casuais, fÃ£s ou nÃ£o de Simuladores Imersivos ou Puzzles, e isso a um preÃ§o condizente com o conteÃºdo entregue. Uma experiÃªncia diferenciada e obrigatÃ³ria!

P.S. Um aspecto importante que deve ser mencionado: Gatos - O nome dos computadores no jogo Ã© CAT (Ctrl Alt Terminal) com arte "ASCII" de gatos neles, as cÃ¢meras de selfie sempre tiram fotos de gatos, e as imagens das conquistas tambÃ©m sÃ³ tem gatos. Gatos em todos os lugares. Isso sozinho jÃ¡ faz o jogo valer totalmente a pena :D

Wabbaboy
585 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1
RecommandÃ©
38.0 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 26 octobre 2023
Maybe the best immersive sim I've ever played.

This game poses interesting philosophical questions on the nature of thought and being, it provides numerous solutions to every situation (box stacking, violence, stealth, 'hacking' in the form of control, other kinds of violence, teleportation), and it is truly immersive and draws you in to look at every detail / examine every nook and cranny / engage all of your senses (except smell and taste, thank God). It has a good sense of humor as well!

The final thing I'll praise about the game is something that is hard to get right in immersive sims and that is a sense of stakes; in games like Prey or Deus Ex you don't want to die and there is a tremendous amount of tension and frustration when you do die. You're tied to a character and their fate is important to you. What I'm trying to say is that being a ball of pure consciousness is a huge relief! There ARE stakes... you do WANT to pull off well executed moves... but also there aren't because destruction off whatever body you're in at the time means nothing. The premise of the game allows this to be believable... so it isn't immersion breaking. If you were to take all the tension and stakes out of Prey, it wouldn't make any sense and would in itself break immersion. Honestly, my one fault for another recent immersive sim, Shadows of Doubt, is that sometimes it feels like there are no stakes when they should exist in the setting.

If you are like me and sometimes you have to stop playing other immersive sims because the tension is too much and you REALLY just wanted to relax and play a game, then this is for you. If you crave a challenge THIS GAME IS ALSO FOR YOU. You can dial the difficulty waaaay up and try for other difficult goals.

Really, I cannot think of any downsides to this game. The developer is super responsive in the Steam forums and is clearly a person who understands what is truly enjoyable about immersive sims as a genre.

I'd love to see a fusion of Ctrl Alt Ego and Shadows of Doubt!!! What a masterpiece that would be. Anyway, buy this game now!

Update: I started playing through the missions... they are also extremely well done! These are unique scenarios that offer very specific challenges. Each one feels like a chess puzzle: there is a solution to each scenario, even on the hardest difficulties, so long as you are observant and not too wasteful of the limited resources available. I thought I was done with the game, but after challenging myself to beat Advanced Rocket Surgery on Severe (which I did in just over 10 minutes before work) I feel like my interest is renewed and I'm looking forward to the remaining missions!
 
Great Charade

kÃ¤flex
322 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
25.7 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 22 octobre 2023
Ctrl Alt Ego is awesome. If you enjoy immersive sims or puzzle solving, I think this is a must-buy. It feels sort of like Prey, Portal, and Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy mixed together.

You play a disembodied ego on a space station. While you do have one main body that you use and upgrade, you can possess most of the enemies in the game, and you can also possess things like doors, tiny machines, security systems, and more. Things that have some level of security on them cost ego to possess, whereas the small things like pads or oscilloscopes tend to give you ego when you possess them. This gives you an absurd amount of freedom to solve the puzzles in this game - you could just run in and corrupt various objects into explosives and throw them around, or you could hop around possessing objects to figure out how to stealthily move through a room, or you could just use your excess ego to possess all of the guards in the room and make it a friendly space for you to move through, or you could just skip that room altogether and find a printer on the other side to teleport your body around it. It's pretty crazy how many solutions each room has and how much freedom you have to figure out your own solution.

There is a pretty big difficulty spike near the end of the game, but as long as you've been thorough in your exploration and collected a good number of upgrades, you'll be fine. Even then, I get the notion that you'd be fine if you just played creatively and slowly. It seems difficult to hit a fail state, as there's a lot of ways to do things.

Definitely pick this up if you enjoy immersive sims or puzzle solving.
 
Zebra

Volpa
0
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
2
RecommandÃ©
22.3 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 29 septembre 2023
A hidden gem that truly stands out from the abundance of indie games. Ctrl Alt Ego is an immersive sim that stands on its own feet through a primary game mechanic I have not seen before which makes it feel fun, and original. If you like to play games your way where there are multiple ways of going about achieving the task set out for you then this should be right up your alley. This is one of the very few games that I can say you can play your own way. I was astounded at how many ways I could go about most of the tasks in this game. It is full of very smart wit and maintains a charm throughout that few games are able to offer. The whole game is just a breath of fresh air and it was great to play through something with substantial character the whole way through. The dev is very competent at writing and crafting an interesting game world. This game also has immense replay-ability due to how many skills and upgrades are available. You could do a few runs through the main game with completely different builds which would change the play style considerably. My only regret is that I didn't do my first play through on hard - that was a mistake as it was bit too easy which made me lazy when it came to strategy as guns blazing was an easy option.

This game is fantastic and worth every penny at full price.

TOWELS
0
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
47.7 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 5 septembre 2023
Highly recommended. If you like immersive sims, appreciate British humour, and were annoyed when Maplins, Radio Shack or your local equivalent closed down, then this is for you. By definition it is an immersive sim; a shooter when you want it to be, or a stealth game, or a puzzle game, in whatever proportions suit you.

Ctrl Alt Ego takes a "fail forward" approach to death, in which each defeat is only a minor reset, losing no progress and never leaving the game world, something developers have attempted using various methods since the first Prey. Eventually players will realise that there is no need to save or reload, except to start and end a session. In this sense, Ctrl Alt Ego achieves what Know By Heart set out to do, which is to encourage the player to accept failure, which here is used as a means to learn and continue rather than a series of one-way decisions. Even when you're out of juice, have made a mess and reprinted your robot twenty times, there is always a solution, and this is where the real fun of the game lies. Levels are intricately designed with routes and bypasses to discover, so there's often something else to try.

The plot of the game is well-delivered, using the familiar tools of disembodied voice (which is disembodied for an in-game reason), convenient journal entries and environmental design. Players are strongly encouraged to read everything, as in Control, the narrative is the sum of each part, which builds into a convincing whole.

Again, highly recommended.
 
fitzroy_doll

My personal game of the year for 2022.

1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1
RecommandÃ©
17.7 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 14 aout 2023
One of most immersive games I've played. Taking over devices and enemies is a very unique mechanic. I liked how different the abilities were and how you could modify them and improve them. The campaign took me about 15 hours to complete on my first play through (on moderate mode.) It's very re-playable and there are so many different approaches you can take to the levels. That along with the sandbox mode I think Â£16 is a very good price. There were only a few minor glitches which will probably be patched in future updates. Music, sound effects and level design were all amazing. It performed very well on my PC staying consistent at 180FPS with almost no frame drops or stutters running at 1440p with DLDSR (I have an RTX 3070 and a Ryzen 7 5700x.) The ending was a bit dull especially with the buildup in the last level though.

Clump
0
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
22.8 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 11 juillet 2023
This is a modern classic. It will fit right alongside games like Portal, System Shock, Rez - weird, innovative, interesting, amazing games.

The closest comparison I can make is Portal, (or MAYBE Prey) - this is a free form (lol) puzzle game with multiple ways to complete each objective in an area.

The writing is great, the graphics are stylized and fun, and the gameplay is super innovative and interesting.

It's a must play, especially if you love weird games.

*Edit - After beating the game, I stand by the above review but with the caveat that I would give it "only" a 9/10. It stumbles a bit on the ending, which is still interesting and makes sense story-wise, but is a bit abrupt and a tiny bit unsatisfying. Still an amazing game.*

RecommandÃ©
22.9 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 25 juin 2023
Here are things this game provides that you probably did not know you need:

Rare plot - check
Your choice of violence level per mission - yes
Sandboxey systems at your disposal - absolutely
Surprise outcome behind every corner and on any action - you bet
Cute pups that bark - adorable
Cats - sure

UI jankiness is something you should get used to, but sometimes it adds to the tension (i've lost count of how many times i made something explode in my face instead of grabbing it or pushing it away) and death is not the end, rather a moment to reexamine your tactic and get back into action via nearest controlable entity.

The level design is great, exploring the CRS offices and Cloud station was a blast. The core gameplay of controlling different hosts was a brilliant idea by the devs that never got old. Throw in a slew of different powers/upgrades and it's clear this game has tons of replay value and promotes creativity. i will definitely replay it and keep an eye on what the devs do next.

It is really hard to explain this game, but shortest i can do is: "Do X. I don't care how, just do it. There is no wrong ways to do it."

This game offers so much freedom in approach, that i doubt i have ever seen in any other game with objectives. It starts a bit on rails-ish (as much as it can in this game) but only to show you new most important mechanics. Play this game.

P.S.: You can add ~100 hrs to my playtime since i played mostly on steam free copy (my laptop cant connect to internet :<).

Pokemonchase
344 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
20.1 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 9 juin 2023
The game is free to a fault, where obstacles act less like obstacles and more like suggestions on what you might not want to do for most of the game â€” you can pretty much trivialise every level by possessing an enemy, and running through with invisibility when needed.

The gameplay and world-building are top-notch im-sim stuff, but I found that the pacing of the game dragged around halfway through, and it only really got better when I further upgraded my character to completely trivialise the actual challenges, so the game became more about exploring the station at my own pace than actively struggling to make it through.

Overall, this game feels more like an exploration sandbox than most other immersive simulators, making me disengage at times, but it really has no major flaws in my mind, and I would recommend it to anyone who would find this intriguing based on its Steam page.
 
Dani Filth

superremeo31
76 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
3 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
18.7 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 24 mai 2023
No game since Prey has left me feeling like it was made specifically for me... well, until Ctrl Alt Ego. Prey is the easy point of comparison, as both are immersive sims set on a space station in total chaos with obvious inspiration from System Shock. However, to an even greater extent than Prey, Ctrl Alt Ego allows for more creative player freedom and progression in what (if any) upgrades you want to take to solve the many challenges throughout. If you liked Prey (or any other immersive sim), then do yourself a favor and don't sleep on Ctrl Alt Ego.

Also, my first play through was entirely on a Steam Deck. I'd say that performance was Good while playing on low to medium settings.
 
RoetKerLauncher

Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 9 mai 2023
Genuinely a surprise hit for me. I enjoy games similar to it like Deus Ex (for the hacking). And I love to bounce around systems. But I did not think I would so thoroughly enjoy this as I did. I am glad I not only bought it, but bought it for full price. Was completely worth the $20 for me.

The amount of ways you can get around every single problem in the game is incredible. You also have the option of not dealing with many of the problems entirely if you prefer. Buy it.
 
Reina Weis
0
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
28.2 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 7 mai 2023
Great immersive sim that is incredibly creative.

It kind of falls into the same pitfalls as some other immersive sims like Prey in that enemy and weapon (not ability) variety is somewhat limited, but they do a great job with what they do have. There are a lot of ways to deal with most situations in the game, whether it be stealth, combat, or variations inbetween.

Want to directly shoot/drill things yourself, and then vacuum up the parts to refill your health'/ammo? Sure.
Want to cloak/teleport around and avoid everything, or move right in front of them using an unsuspecting "allied" robot you've taken over? Go for it.
Want to amass a pile of ego and take over your enemies (or even spawn your own), and defeat everything using a sort of laser shooting proxy army? You bet.
Hell, you want to run up to an enemy, turn them into a bomb, and then chuck/shift them across the room into everyone else, or let that bomb infect everyone else and turn them into bombs too? You bet you can do that.

The enemies are really weird in that way too; some are 3D printers that don't destroy a target, but store them, and if you take them over you can re-place them. Some turn enemies into weightless husks that can be re-energized using health, allowing you use that enemy to move them wherever you like (chucking them into a room perhaps), re-energizing them using another robot, and preparing to destroy everything from there while they are considered non-hostile as you teleport ammo/juice to them using download. Unfortunately, as mentioned there are only a few real enemies; if there is a sequel in the future, hopefully this number is increased (maybe doubled?).

It plays a lot more like a puzzle game then other immersive sims do, in that there are a lot of optional situations that you can solve by thinking carefully about your abilities, but if you mess up the puzzle you can't fix it. Thankfully if you mess these optional puzzles up then you don't lose out (notably with disks/new ability unlocks, as there are more then enough disks in the game to unlock them all, even if you can't come even close to upgrading them all with all worms. Plus saving is infinite and save points are always near-by these, so just make sure to save often if you aren't willing to leave anything behind.

If you are into immersive sims (shooters, stealth games, or maybe even puzzle games), I fully recommend this.

0
3 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1
RecommandÃ©
14.3 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 3 mai 2023
Ctrl Alt Ego might be one of my favorite "immersive-sims" at the moment.

It's heavily influenced by System Shock and Prey (2017), but is also quite different in that it has less of an emphasis on "conventional" combat and more on alternative approaches and general problem solving.

In a lot of ways Ctrl Alt Ego feels like it's what you get if you grow an immersive sim from the starting point of a first person puzzle"game like Portal instead of from an FPS or RPG.
 
Paul Debrion
657 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1
RecommandÃ©
22.8 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 3 mai 2023
An excellent game. It started off slowly and I wasn't sure I was going to like it, but the game soon grew on me. There was a certain point probably 8 hours into my playthrough where everything started to click and I could handle just about any situation the game threw at me using the multitude of tools I had acquired along the way. Good graphics, good replayability, enjoyable story, and an overall great experience.

Play this game. It deserves more love.
 
Reliable Grandma
0
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
18.0 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 25 avril 2023
Gonna be honest, almost dropped the game at first. It's a bit slow on the uptake imo as it's rather linear at the start, or at least in a sense that I felt I was overthinking the challenges. I was admittedly a bit irrationally determined to play as if I was doing some challenges, even if I had already failed them. That said, once the game started to open up a few hours in, I was pretty enthralled.

There is just so much to remember in such a good way, and a lot of options. It really felt like I was rewarded for my creativity, and even when I saw that there was another way, it never really felt like the Deus Ex: HR thing where you ALWAYS just missed a vent. To be clear, I did overlook vents a good few times, but often they comboed with requiring other skills, or were genuinely well hidden. By the time I thought the game was ending, it still had another 5-8 hours of content. And to be honest, the only reason I beat this as fast as I did is through utilizing a very specific unit to it's extreme. The unit is borderline game breaking, but honestly by that point in the game it felt earned.

Vague story spoiler: TBH the ending felt a bit uh... Idk, it was appropriate.. but felt disappointing and like I messed something up, but the dev has explicitly stated there is one ending. Idk, there were a few twists along the way, and I was expecting something at least bittersweet.

That all said, I didn't play the game for the story, and I've heard this game compared to Deus Ex, the original. If that's true, then I should go play Deus Ex, because I want more of this game. Oh, also Cats
 
Confusing Name

Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 19 avril 2023
Honestly this is just one of the best immersive sims I've ever played- More just the best. It's what GOT ME into immersive sims. Outside of a few hurdles there were never any areas where I felt like I had no idea what to do. There was all of *one* instance where I couldn't do something due to not having the right tool- everything else worked fine with whatever I just happened to have.

The one thing I'd request from the devs would be a new game plus or infinite worms mode- Some way to play around with all your fun tools once you've beaten the game. But otherwise? Aesthetics, gameplay, tone, themes, all of it are 10/10

237 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
Personne n'a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
3.0 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 24 mars 2023
Ctrl Alt Ego

Drawn to 'Ctrl Alt Ego' for its immersive simulation, akin to favorites like Prey and Dishonored, I found myself in the midst of an experience that's more exploratory than traditional gameplay.

Pro:
+ Uniquely unusual game that offers a fresh experience.
+ The ego system and interactions with objects are innovative and engaging.

Contra:
- Challenging to get into due to the need for self-guided discovery and understanding.
- Controls could be improved for a better gameplay experience.
- Art direction and overall presentation fall short of expectations.
- Lacks guidance for players, making navigation and progression often confusing.
- While the system mechanics are interesting, the game misses the mark in worldbuilding compared to similar titles by studios like Arkane

Conclusion:
'Ctrl Alt Ego' is a GOOD game for those who enjoy experimentation and exploration within a unique framework.
 
Charles_Vane

A delightfully clever immersive sim and a breath of fresh air for the genre as a whole. It may not be the prettiest immersive sim, but it more than makes up for that with the care and intelligence put into its design. If you are a fan of the genre and looking for an immersive sim that will continuously surprise you with what shenanigans it will let you pull to solve its puzzles and challenges, Ctrl Alt Ego is for you.

284 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
51.6 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 3 mars 2023
Ctrl Alt Ego is an experience that I cannot recommend enough.
It has so much charm in the dialogue and humor. The music is wonderful, I definitely recommend getting the soundtrack as well. The replay-ability is very high, as there are so many different ways to approach problems that can drastically change the way you view the entire layout of a level. The tools this game gives you access to allows you to get as creative or direct as you feel like.
There are multiple ways to solve puzzles in this game, and the developer encourages you to embrace the jank and considers any possible solution a valid one. Go ahead, break this game, it's alright, there are no rules.
Also you get to play as all the robots so you gotta get this game or else you'll be trapped in meat space during the great extinction event.
 
Booger
288 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
24.1 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 1 mars 2023
Ctrl Alt Ego is one of the best examples of modern immersive sim design (think Deus Ex or Prey with more whimsy and creativity).
The gameplay is primarily comprised of open ended environments with a set objective. Where CAE excels is by not funneling the player into a set A, B or C path. The player is allowed to use their own ingenuity to solve the problems, and the further I got in the game the more I realized just how open those systems really are. It truly felt like my only limits were my own creativity.
Highly recommended for anyone that enjoys immersive sims, player driven mechanics, and sci-fi narratives. Plus, an absolute steal for the price
 
Shalashaska

Very fun immersive sim game. I had to play on the no puke settings, but still had a lot of fun playing through the world of this game. Play as a disembodied consciousness that exists within machine bodies and can switch freely (usually) between different mechanical hosts. The game gives incentives for a wide range of play styles. while never feeling like you're genuinely breaking the puzzles set forth for you.

RecommandÃ©
5.2 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 21 fÃ©vrier 2023
This game is cool! Geist crossed with Portal crossed with Deus Ex. Clunky as all hell but that's an intentional part of the design, its a good kind of janky. Real fun, tons of creative ways to solve problems. In the first level I found a way to both prop fly and clip out of bounds, and a little secret left by the developers made sure I knew they knew what I was up to. Story and writing are (so far) charming but not the focus, and that's probably for the best in a game like this one. Give it a go, if you like immersive sims and/or breaking janky games, you'll have fun.

Tokoroto
1,650 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
22.1 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 2 fÃ©vrier 2023
I had just came off of playing prey 2017 and loving it, so its not to be taken lightly when i say this is my new gold standard for immersive sims and easily the best game I played in 2022. It has an unrivaled sense of freedom and creativity in its mechanics that make it much closer to a puzzle game than a shooter in the best way.

The ability to "jump" (not actually jumping in this game, but its the closest equivalent) is an optional upgrade that you can go through the game without ever getting. That's how ridiculous the level of freedom you have to create your own solutions gets.

If i had to give one critique, I'd say the game drags a little bit around the last quarter but its very minor and hardly sours my overall opinion on it. (I also got a little bit lost in one area which is probably the largest contributor to that feeling) It's only really notable because of how good the pacing was prior in introducing fresh scenarios constantly.
 
Louie Gaming

2,861 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
11.4 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 23 janvier 2023
Very fresh and very fun. Upgrades are very accessible from the outset and are utilized in ways I really don't see in other games. Once you get the hang of it it really feels like you can -actually- tackle any given situation any way you want (Stealth, shoot em up, control your enemies and use them to fight, take down one guy and turn him into a pile of explosives that will slowly propogate throughout the entire room until one of them goes off spontaneously 30 seconds later killing everything including you). Chaotic but incredible.

Lots of programmer humor which I ought to hate but honestly it comes off very sincere and the world feels cohesive in spite of being based entirely off these â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ jokes. The ending in particular has no right to hit that hard in a game with this sort of tone. Fantastic work, wonderful game.
 
Joey The Big J Jojo
2,461 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
13.3 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 22 janvier 2023
This is an immersive sim through and through. Other famous immersive sims use immersive sim mechanics as a means to an end, such as presenting a fantasy of some sorts (like being a thief). Everything in CTRL ALT EGO however, from the story to the artstyle serves the end goal of making the best immersive sim experience. The game starts slow but gets better and better with each passing chapter. Many of your gaming assumptions will be challenged such as 'what it means to actually complete a level'. The game offers an unprecedented amount of freedom, and playing it to its full potential basically feels like sequence breaking.

Wholly recommended.
 
nastybandicoot
233 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1
RecommandÃ©
36.8 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 19 janvier 2023
I'm only a couple hours in but this is quickly becoming one of my favorite games of all time. I've never really played another immersive sim before, but if they're as good as this then I definitely have some catching up to do. The game has such a robust toolset that you can approach problems in any number of ways, and the fact that all ways are the right way is just so incredible and satisfying to pull off. I cannot even put into words how much of a joy it is playing this game, by far the most underrated game of 2022.

Definitely worth playing and well worth it's price!

This is a game for the curious! I loved my first playthrough and I already have ideas I want to try on a second. Easy recommendation even at full price.

I'd recommend turning off the 2 Hud Assist options once you feel comfortable with what the game wants you to collect. Every thing you can collect makes a certain noise and a big part of my enjoyment of this game was hearing something and trying to find a way to get to that item.
 
LolCat
0
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
17.7 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 15 janvier 2023
I buy games fairly often and in all my years of gaming I haven't come across anything quite like this one before. This is a real gem that deserves a closer look rather than mistaking it for something it's not like I initially did.

To put it as simple as I can it's a puzzler where you control a robot on a space station trying to solve various tasks and progress to other areas as an omnious situation is occuring. There is no single intended or preset way to solve anything like you find in every other game. It's a laugh trying out different ideas or just wing it in a mundane way. Anything goes.

An important mechanic is that you can jump to and control different robots you see or devices that do different things. There's even upgrade disks and other stuff I've yet to find out about. There's tons of stuff on the station you can interact with and do things so many different ways this is a game I'm looking forward to replaying over and over.

If it at least sounds interesting try the demo as it's hard to describe, you need to experience it for yourself.

84 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
18.3 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 6 janvier 2023
Overall Ctrl Alt Ego is a great immersive sim, although some odd design choices and balancing problems sour the experience a bit in the back half of the game. I would recommend this game for anyone new to the genre because of how well it tutorializes not just its own mechanics and systems but also just the basic idea of having fun with the creative problem solving that's emblematic of the genre, and it does all this with a death system that is not very punishing (without feeling cheap), which encourages experimentation. The first half of the game also dodges some of the annoyances of other games in the genre with a combination of more linear level design (that manages not to ever feel restrictive) and predictable enemies. The core gameplay mechanic of being able to look through most objects in the game combined with a generous usage of one-way transparent objects means that you'll usually have more or less perfect information for each encounter. This makes the game feel like a series of tightly designed puzzles that allow for a seemingly endless number of ways to approach them.

There are some problems that arise around the halfway mark that can be summarized into three categories: more open level design with worse information available, a new annoying enemy type, and poor balancing. First, that new enemy type is annoying due to how it moves extremely erratically with confusing physics. It goes against what makes the early game work so well with predictable enemies. This gets compounded with the larger, more open levels that appear later in the game. It becomes harder to understand exactly what's in the next room, and these new enemies are often placed in spots you couldn't possibly have known before they aggro.

This kind of design in theory can lead to more improvisation, but because how much more unpredictable the game became I found myself just resorting to my most versatile tool, which was the gun. The gunplay feels awful with very little hit feedback (and the fact that the annoying enemy is rapidly flying across your entire screen), but it's still incredibly powerful and your best way of dealing with a surprising enemy that gets the jump on you. This brings us the third problem I have which could rectify reckless gun usage, which is the poor balancing towards the later parts of the game. The enemies, both in power and in numbers, simply don't scale nearly as much as the player does. On top of that, resource management gets less and less important as the game progresses because of one tool that lets you suck up dead enemies for health and fuel. The game simply required much less brain power as you got closer to the end.

One last complaint is that there's one character whose volume is seemingly kept at max and isn't affected by any of the volume sliders. I get that the developer wanted this character to be imposing, but I get value out of having undamaged eardrums more so I had to waste time balancing the game's volume in windows.

Despite these problems, the game still stays fun throughout, even if it doesn't maintain that 10/10 feeling throughout.
 
richgamebuddy

Presentation was the barrier keeping me from playing and inderstanding. After an hour I started to like the presentation and went "FULL IMMSIM". BTW there's a free demo. Try It.

Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 29 dÃ©cembre 2022
Easily one of the best deus ex/immersive sims I played in years, it's a cleverly designed game where the slow build up of abilities and the many ways it can open up a level feels natural. Late game I was still coming up with new ways to solve problems and it all feels somehow both by design and unintentional. The story also creeps into you, the comedy at start can feel a bit one note but it just seethes in and then you start noticing the deeper seedier underbelly.

1,065 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
33.5 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 29 dÃ©cembre 2022
How to explain in a few words what is Ctrl Alt Ego?
Imagine Dishonored was made not by Arkane, but by quirky programmers very found of British sci-fi. The setting is not a sophisticated steampunk Victorian England, but futuristic space stations where sentient robots roam. Instead of assassinations your objectives are bypassing robotic security or taking control of specific systems, and instead of blink you can hop between cybernetic hosts and take control of them.

If you fear an indie title could not be on par to the high standards set by modern immersive sims produced by professional studios, then I am happy to say that these doubts are completely out of place.
The game is well optimized and carefully polished: I never encountered moments of frustrations due to long loading times, fluctuating frame rate, inputs not read properly, features missing or crudely implemented.
If you do not trust a random review, there is a demo available which I strongly recommend you try. It features the prologue and the first two levels of the campaign and it should give you a good idea if this game would be of your liking.

Does the game live up to the expectations set by this sample? In my opinion, not only it does that, but it manages to far exceed them! If the demo presents the base mechanics and the most common gameplay elements you will be facing, then the rest of the game presents levels and challenges progressively more elaborate, which will let you unleash all your creativity and lateral thinking.
Cannot wait to smash enemy bots to pieces? You will have available drills, explosives, guns, sci-fi rays to wreak havoc. Maybe you prefer subtlety? You can perfectly sneak by all the security by concocting distractions, becoming invisible with a cloak device or teleporting yourself directly past the guards.
The level design perfectly complements the tools available to the player and offers various situations where it is up to you finding the optimal solution or creating it.

In conclusion, this is well-deserved a thumb up. Ctrl Alt Ego is not just an attempt to emulate a specific design school, but a proof that the principles of this school were fully understood and were originally conjugated to create a fresh and unique experience.
 
MaskedFelon
323 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
78.1 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 21 dÃ©cembre 2022
CTRL ALT EGO is indeed the 21st century's version of N64 Silicon Valley, famously known for being able to take over enemy minds and their respective, unique abilities to solve puzzles and advance the game. To explain upfront, there is a "mana/ammo" pool for how many actions or skills you can execute on a particular level. But this is the genius of it all. With a refreshing take on the physics and item-interaction systems, you can get creative to find unconventional and/or cheaper solutions. Yes, of course you can brute force your way around with a shield and shoot robots in the face with a shotgun, but you'll soon find yourself very low on resources as you progress. Or here's an example you can try:

A high level robot is blocking your path and direct combat will result in your death. You can carefully gather a bunch of explosive canisters that scattered across the map. Then use a skill to "fault" the canisters which adds multiplier to the explosive damage. You take over the mind of a particular robot which can teleport the canisters close an enemy of interest. With all the pieces set, you spring the trap from a safe distance by using another skill to "whirlwind" the faulted canisters. The canisters get jostled around by the whirlwind and ignite the most overkill explosion, all just to kill one robot...

Elaborate? Yes. Satisfying? HELL YES! There are a good selection of other kind of "skills" that let you get more creative (cloaking for example). The hours melt by as you let your madman imagination loose on finding clever and satisfying ways to kill robots. Or yeah you can just shoot them in the face with a shotgun if you prefer simpler means... Either way, this game is a solid "yes" recommend.
 
Runaway Sparrow
0
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile

RecommandÃ©
18.5 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 7 dÃ©cembre 2022
This is one of the best, most unique games I've played in a long time. Good story, fascinating environments, unique game play. And many, many, many ways to go about doing the different tasks. I don't even really know how to describe it in a way that would do it right.

You're a robot that roams space stations and mind-controls other robots. Stealth, combat, puzzle, all kinds of different approaches. And then you learn it's way deeper and more complicated than that. Highly recommend!

554 produits enregistrÃ©s

1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
37.8 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 29 novembre 2022
This is an excellent game, one of the best I have played in some time. Has some very unique concepts and is very immersive (which is the idea of course). There are various methods to complete each area, so you can play each level multiple times in a different way - fight, sneak or solve puzzles. I found this just made me want to come back again and again for more. To think that this is an indie game, a lot of work has gone into making it a unique experience, and the developer is still making improvements and fixing bugs. I highly recommend you play this game!

Having now played to the end, the game just kept giving and giving and giving. A few times I thought the game was coming to an end, then there was a whole new area to explore. I also give lots of kudos to the developers who are keen to continue to work on the game regularly fixing bugs and adding features. There has also been a couple of larger updates too. All in all, I think this is one of the best immersive sims I've played. I'm hoping that the developers add more levels with some additional DLC to expand the game further (a full sequel would take a lot of effort of course). I'd be very happy to pay to have this extra DLC - finger crossed.

Definitely you should play this if you like this type/genre of game. Absolutely Fantastic 10/10.
 
knightmare28

3 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
59.5 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 26 novembre 2022
One of the best immersive sims you can buy. For those who care about graphics, I find it really grows on you, and has a certain charm. The gameplay is the main feature, with comparisons being made to the original Deus Ex, which I'd say are pretty fair. There's a lot of creativity and ways to solve problems- it's very fun playing multiple ways too. I've gone through 4 playthroughs and 100%'d the game, and each playthrough held notable distinctions in how I solved an assortment of problems, with revelations being made in the level design and interactions in my last playthrough. It really is only limited by how the player decides how to approach these problems. Main notable gripe is that physics can be a bit jank- with a few annoyances, but given that it's an indie developer, I can excuse it pretty easily, especially since it's never really a huge game-breaking problem

Dr.Gonzo1836
1,032 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
2 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1
RecommandÃ©
62.3 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 7 novembre 2022
My 21 hours are split into 2 playthroughs, one around 13 hours, and the next 6 hours, which I challenged myself to pacifist and full stealth. I will follow that up with the fact that I have a large backlog, and that there are games that I haven't even finished, nonetheless followed up with a second playthrough, and I only want to play more.
The amount of ways you can tackle a problem is astounding. Even on my latest playthrough, I noticed new vents and alternate routes, enemy behaviors, and weird mechanics that made me think "What can I do with this?". Possess a certain enemy? Guess what, you get an infinite fuel version of a very powerful resource gathering tool. See a tiny crack? Just teleport yourself through. See a certain giant firewall? Sure you could use the game's given solution to smuggle your bot through, but there is also a vent to skip it behind a wall of barrels. This is only a handful of stuff I noticed.
Best part is that there is no filler areas, every area has some new solution or reaction to exploit. The game isn't too hard, but the real fun is trying to get through the areas while spending the least amount of resources or by challenging yourself with a constraint like the aformentioned pacifist or full stealth. (Those bad bugs can burn in hell though lol)
My only small issue is the two "Bossfights", which are just healthbars with story significance, one of which is the butt of a joke.
Overall I'd give the game a solid 9.5/10. I'd fully recommend buying the game, even if its not on sale. I'll look forward to whatever the devs bring next!
 
Macawesome75

cyynapse
239 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
Personne n'a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
26.7 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 22 octobre 2022
Rating is yes because I like puzzle games and if you get this on a sale, you'll have some fun, but at full price I would say no. I'm assuming this will have some sales being as that it's on Steam, so get it somewhere around 30% off or greater and enjoy it in between AAA releases or whatever.

I really enjoyed this game. The puzzle elements of it are non-linear and there are some rock paper scissors style elements to how you solve things. The storyline is interesting. I didn't have any performance issues unless I got a lot of drops from dispatching an enemy. I did have an issue where I couldn't swap tools unless I hit escape and went back in.

That all being said, the flipside to the above paragraph is that I enjoyed this game in spite of some of the parts of this game. Your choices in how to approach parts of this game, while numerous, will be spammed all the time. If you're loud and like to hurt things, you have grenades and a shotgun (eventually), if you're stealthy, you'll use cloaking and smaller robots, and in either event you can either vacuum up walls or teleport around using one of your skills. This can make the gameplay repetitive quickly. I wouldn't say there's a lot of puzzles, either. There's creative ways to deal with a situation, so the game is kind of what you make it. And the ending is a bit overrated, as someone who's played a lot of games that have real mind-benders in them. For example, if you're looking for a big twist such as Spec Ops: The Line, you won't find it here.

I played this for 27 hours at the time of writing, and I paid the current full retail price for it. I wouldn't consider this unless it's on a really good sale, since to me I would expect roughly 50 cents paid per hour of gameplay to be a good deal, and this is double that.
 
SHAKE

Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 21 octobre 2022
In the time I've played I've put 4 complete runs in, and every single one was different in its own way. You really can play it just about any way you like, and no way is going to be any less engaging than any of the others. A curious storyline. Few, but interesting characters. Heaps of things to discover, be they placed by the developer or discovering your own methods of getting through the environments. Pick up Ctrl Alt Ego, and show the bots who's the biggest ego maniac on the station!

307 produits enregistrÃ©s
0
3 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
1
RecommandÃ©
9.6 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 1 octobre 2022
I will be honest this is a game I put off on checking out for awhile. I guess partly because I had concerns on what a "puzzle imsim" would be like as im not a huge puzzle game person unless the gameplay hook or story is really good (ex: Portal). I am glad to say what concerns I had shortly dissipated after the first few hours and Ctrl Alt Ego was a game that really grew on me in the end.

Lets start with the good:
-The game has fun writing, game world and voice acting
-The whole "take control" of various systems and robots all while juggling a bunch of versatile powers is really unique gameplay gimmick that doesn't ever get old (it feels kinda unfair to even call it a gimmick).
-Overall some very good imsim level design here, plenty of loops and alternative paths as well as fairly unique challenges for the player to overcome
-Game doesn't over stay its welcome but is also well worth the money. If anything I wish they charged more, this is a seriously good 8-10 hour experience. Furthermore the more I played of it the more I really liked the game as I acquired more powers and learned more things about the game.
-I haven't tried the standalone missions, but the main game offers a lot of replayability in terms of ways of completing tasks and abilities to acquire.

The "Bad":
-I'm a bit lukewarm on the two boss fights in the game, I struggled to find alternate solutions besides direct confrontation. While I wouldn't want the devs to spell it out for me, some more hints or options would have gone a long way.
-There was like one bit of geo missing in the tech labs that showed the exterior sky box
-While I fully understand combat is not the main focus of the game, at times it could feel a bit frustrating because the game can occasionally be a bit stingy with its "juice" and "ego" resources which I felt sometimes could reduce the amount of creative options I could try and I ended up sticking with tried and true shotguns to robot faces (whereas something like Prey or SS2 you rarely run out Psi when it comes to experimenting). However maybe its just a me problem like with the boss fights.

Overall a hidden gem for sure, please don't over look this cool game!
8.5/10
 
Safavi

I am not much for writing reviews but feel not making one for this game is doing it a disservice. And it deserves to get more attention. It is truly a gem and seems to be getting overlooked.

Ctrl, Alt, Ego has multiple ways to approach the environmental puzzles, various different paths to take, and is well written.
It feels like it will have good replay value.

I have not finished it yet but after 11 hours I can confidently say Ctrl, Alt, Ego is a 8/10 game easy.

This game is amazing! It manages to challenge you in really fun ways, and it never ceases to reward you for good plays, clever tactics, and keen observation.
Hidden paths and well thought challenges are everywhere and you will never find a challenge that you won't be able to best with good wits or quick fingers, this game really tickles your brain, and when you find a secret door or manage to beat (or sneak past!) all the enemies in a room it always feels sooooo satisfying. This game is wholeheartedly recommended!

RecommandÃ©
21.0 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 25 septembre 2022
This is a fantastic immersive sim. There are a lot of creative solutions to the puzzles and the mechanics are quite fun. If you like Prey or Cruelty Squad or really any other immersive sim you should love this one. Hopping from one electronic device to another is smooth and easy to do.

The powers, programs, are a blast to use. I especially like the drill and the shifting of large objects. Faulting canisters and chucking them at robots is always a good time too. The game has a good amount of upgrades to collect and the rewards are worth doing a bit of exploration to get them.

I level design is great in the beginning, middle and ending areas. I had a blast throughout my time playing the game. I recommend it to anybody really.

Personne n'a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
15.9 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 24 septembre 2022
A surprisingly great immersive sim game. Mechanically, this game blows many out of the park!

However, there is one major drawback.
The very bland aesthetics and design make the immersive sim less so. What do I mean? Well, so many places and rooms do not have a proper tell as to what they are. If were in the security room, I expect a lot of hostile robots there. Or, if were in a bar, I expect a lot of beer bottles. If were in a BUG assembly station, I expect to see many things regarding BUGs. But instead, we dont. The rooms do not make sense. Just look at the space stations. It does not really give much sense, and that kills a lot of the immersive sim planning. Just look at the pipes, how they twirl for no reason.

The only good level In my oppinion is the final 2 levels. CRS and the final one. These levels had what made sense. And I actually made sense of the weirdness because of that. I managed to map out and create a plan, while before those levels, I just "Went forward" and the rooms were just different rooms arranged seemingly randomly.

Still great game tho.
 
Crafekster
0
1 personne a trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
39.4 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 23 septembre 2022
Ctrl Alt Ego is an amusing hybrid of puzzle, exploration, stealth and destruction. You're free to decide how to solve problems in a fairly open manner, but the progression of the game's story is fairly straightforward. Although you're playing in a first-person perspective it doesn't play like a traditional FPS, but something new and strange.

You play as a disembodied consciousness able to control machines and computers, and you'll also have access to a special robot that can be upgraded with new abilities. The story is delivered in a lighthearted way but touches on some interesting themes which you'll discover through optional notes, similar to other games in the Immersive Sim genre.

If you want you could upgrade your Bug with a shotgun right from the start and try blasting your way through the game, but the real fun is in experimenting with the game's kit of weird and wonderful abilities like remotely dominating enemy robots, teleporting yourself out of trouble, or setting traps that your enemies will run into.

The game's slightly dated visuals and clumsy robot physics add a certain charm to an already very unique game, and it's got a playable demo so give it a try and see what kind of mess you can make of things.
 
Bubbinska

RecommandÃ©
8.4 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 19 septembre 2022
Really enjoyable Immersive Sim so far. Demo is very generous (got sucked in for about two hours) so plenty of time to give it a go to make up your own mind.

Does take a little bit to get used to the mechanics and some of the tutorials can be a little vague/ hidden behind hints but if you pay close attention to your environment and experiment (which the game encourages) you'll quickly see the flexibility the game allows it's players to have.

It embraces the 'here's all the tools, off you go' mindset and the level design gives so many routes and option to tackle problems, I keep wondering what else I could have done if I go back - already thinking about a second play through before I've finished the first. Tickles the problem solving brain just right.

One of the best games I've played this year. As an Immersive Sim, it avoids the Play Your Way = Play According to Stat Allocation pitfalls that many of these games do, instead providing incredibly tight encounter and puzzle design, mixed with a gloriously abusable toolset.

I had stupid amounts of fun with this. An easy recommend.

RecommandÃ©
15.3 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 5 septembre 2022
truly a hidden gem! took me 15hrs to clear all 8 chapters. (i took it slow, most will probably beat it faster than me.) i've seen many compare this to other popular im-sims, which is why i bought it, but it has so many of its own great ideas that it truly sets itself apart from those other titles. it's not an imitator - it's a peer and an equal to those other titles!

it shocked me how many tools i had to problem solve and to explore the world. it really allows for the creativity and expression that i really look for in a good game, and especially a good im-sim.

the story is more compelling than i expected.

it did take me about an hour to get hooked, but i'm so glad i gave it that time! it is one of the best games i've played this year!

RecommandÃ©
39.0 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 4 septembre 2022
yep, probs a new classic imersive sim if you ask me.
I was kinda scared that the whole, disembodied counsciousness thing would end up being tiring and more of a gimmick rather than anything else. but I was wrong, gameplay wise, the numerous bots and equipments you're allowed to use can shake up the gameplay quite a bit.

althought one of my complaint would be that same upgrades feel abit redundant (for example the gun and the drill, wich both essentially acehive the same thing but one is much harder to properly use and feels more like a point sink than the other.).
apart from that, the upgrades don't feel out of place in universe and still fit the aesthetic of the game rather well.
in terms of level design and secrets, the maps/chapters are big enough to hide alot of,upgrade points (who make a sound if you're close enough to one, wich has been really usefull).
so yeah, I'd recommend this game to anyone who's already familiar with the immersive sim genra or just likes puzzle games.
